results.title: At Mount Arafat, Water Fights and Prayers — for Peace and, Yes, for a Husband
results.abstract: Diaa Hadid, a Times correspondent in Mecca for the hajj, observed the latest trends there and confronted a mountain of water bottles.

results.title: The View From Syria as a Cease-Fire Takes Effect
results.abstract: Syrians celebrated the Eid holiday on Monday, and shared in skepticism of the truce: “Here, people can’t believe anything. But they are always waiting for peace.”
results.byline: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

multimedia.caption: A man and his son prayed at the grave of a relative in the rebel-held town of Douma, just east of Damascus, on Monday.

results.title: It’s Not the Bullets Forcing Yemeni Troops Off the Battlefield. It’s the Pay.
results.abstract: Officials in Yemen are struggling to contain the growing anger of pro-government fighters over delayed payments from the Saudi Arabia-led coalition.
results.byline: By SAEED AL-BATATI and NOUR YOUSSEF

results.title: Syria Is Calmer but Cautious as Cease-Fire Begins
results.abstract: The truce, which has drawn skepticism, led to a reduction of violence in its early hours, but there were some reported violations by both sides.
results.byline: By ANNE BARNARD and RICK GLADSTONE

multimedia.caption: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, center, in the Damascus suburb of Daraya on Monday morning, in a photograph released by the official Syrian news agency. Rebels had long held the suburb, but surrendered it last month.

results.title: With U.S. Election in Sight, Ban Ki-moon Seeks Quick Action on Climate Accord
results.abstract: Heeding a threat of withdrawal by Donald J. Trump, the secretary general wants at least 55 countries to commit to the pact for at least the next four years.

results.title: Mexico City’s Organ Grinders, Once Beloved, Feel Shunned
results.abstract: While their numbers may be growing, organists worry that a younger generation does not share the desire to preserve their culture and fails to appreciate the craft.

results.title: Jutta Limbach, First Woman to Lead Germany’s Highest Court, Dies at 82
results.abstract: Ms. Limbach, who was 11 when World War II ended, also led a commission to mediate disputes about the restitution of art seized by the Nazis.

results.title: David Cameron Steps Down From His Seat in British Parliament
results.abstract: The former British prime minister said he is leaving the House of Commons because his continued presence would be a distraction to the new government.

results.title: Mother’s Killing of Children in Rural China Spurs Debate About Inequality
results.abstract: The case of a mother who killed herself and her four children has ignited concerns about the grim realities rural families face amid rampant inequality.

results.title: South Korea’s President Warns of More Provocations From North
results.abstract: President Park Geun-hye ruled out dialogue with the North, saying that its nuclear program was “not a bargaining chip” but a “present and urgent threat.”

results.title: South Sudan Leaders Amass Great Wealth as Nation Suffers, Report Says
results.abstract: A report by an advocacy group in Washington suggests that a desire to control of natural resources, not an ethnic feud, is at the root of the conflict.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

results.title: Visions of Life on Mars in Earth’s Depths
results.abstract: Far down in a South African gold mine, scientists are studying tiny life-forms that live in eternal darkness. The conditions provide insights into where life might exist elsewhere.

multimedia.caption: A team led by Tullis C. Onstott of Princeton University looking for life-forms that could give insights to possible life elsewhere in the solar system in the Beatrix mine in South Africa.

results.title: Benjamin Netanyahu Draws Fire After Saying Palestinians Support ‘Ethnic Cleansing’
results.abstract: In the latest in a series of videos, Israel’s prime minister assailed Palestinian leaders’ opposition to new West Bank settlements.

results.title: Violence Erupts in Southern India Over Order to Share Water
results.abstract: Protesters in Bangalore threw rocks and set fire to vehicles after the Indian Supreme Court ordered Karnataka State to release river water to neighboring Tamil Nadu.

multimedia.caption: Riot police officers in Bangalore, India, in Karnataka State on Monday after protesters set fire to vehicles. Karnataka was ordered to release water to neighboring Tamil Nadu State.

results.title: Repeat of Austria’s Presidential Runoff Faces a Delay
results.abstract: The country’s interior minister said faulty postal ballots meant the vote should be postponed, another embarrassing glitch in an election originally held in May.

results.title: Militia Seizes Libyan Oil Terminals in Challenge to Government
results.abstract: A militia attacked and seized as many as three major oil terminals, not long after the militia that had held them signed a deal with the unity government to resume oil exports.
results.byline: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and DECLAN WALSH

results.title: Marriage Falls in China, Transforming Finances and Families
results.abstract: The drop in marriage stems in part from China’s aging population, but also reflects that women who once were pushed to wed are exploring new options.
results.byline: By AMIE TSANG and ZHANG TIANTIAN

multimedia.caption: A bride at the Bund, the waterfront in Shanghai. Last year, 12 million Chinese couples registered for marriage, making it the second consecutive year the number has declined.
A bride at the Bund, the waterfront in Shanghai. Last year, 12 million Chinese couples registered for marriage, making it the second consecutive year the number has declined.

results.title: Conservative Party in Croatia Wins Parliamentary Elections
results.abstract: The Croatian Democratic Union captured 61 seats, more than the rival Social Democrats but short of a clear governing majority.

results.title: With Spain in Political Deadlock, Catalans Renew Calls for Independence
results.abstract: Hundreds of thousands took to the streets of Barcelona and four other cities to urge their leaders to push for separation from Spain.

results.title: Angela Merkel’s Problems in Germany Could Challenge Europe, Too
results.abstract: The chancellor is under growing political pressure over her migration policy at a time when the Continent is looking for strong leadership.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in Berlin last week. As next year’s national elections approach, she is more politically vulnerable than at any time since her early days in office.

results.title: How Countries Like the Philippines Fall Into Vigilante Violence
results.abstract: Social scientists who study extrajudicial killings say the real story is more complicated — and more tragic — than a simple story of good versus evil.

results.title: After Centuries of Loss, Seeds of Hope for Argentina’s Indigenous People
results.abstract: Ranquel communities have emerged as patient champions of indigenous rights in a nation that is conflicted about the past and about the appropriate response now.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: Fermín Acuña, vice president of the Ranquel Chieftains Council in Santa Rosa, Argentina, at a monument where the prominent 19th-century chieftain Panguithruz Güor is buried. The Ranquel recovered this stretch of land in 2001 and moved his remains there from a museum.

results.title: Ireland Doesn’t Want Apple’s Back Taxes, but the Irish Aren’t So Sure
results.abstract: After six years of belt-tightening and tax increases, many Irish workers say their government’s reluctance to collect $14.5 billion from Apple is unfair.

results.title: Afghan Police Chief Is Killed as He Tries to Turn Tide Against Taliban
results.abstract: The police chief, Gen. Zarawar Zahid, was visiting an outpost when explosives detonated. The Taliban claimed responsibility for his death.
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: Spate of Deadly Attacks in Syria Ahead of Cease-Fire
results.abstract: At least 91 people have been killed in strikes on rebel-held areas in the two days since Russia and the United States declared that a cease-fire would begin on Monday.

multimedia.caption: Syrian men carrying babies made their way through the rubble of destroyed buildings after a reported airstrike on a rebel-held neighborhood in Aleppo on Sunday.

results.title: Tianjin Mayor Caught Up in Xi’s Antigraft Campaign
results.abstract: An announcement said the official was “suspected of severe disciplinary violations,” which usually means taking bribes or other kinds of corruption.

results.title: Few Expect China to Punish North Korea for Latest Nuclear Test
results.abstract: Pyongyang’s aggression is an embarrassment for Beijing, but a collapsed North Korean regime worries Chinese leaders much more, analysts say.

results.title: Turkey’s Suspicious Mind-Set Has Been a Century in the Making
results.abstract: The Turks’ notion of a vast Western conspiracy to undermine their country, with the United States mostly to blame, has its roots in a post-World War I treaty that was never carried out.
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

results.title: Something Old, Something New, Something Borrowed, Something Hindu
results.abstract: A traditional Indian wedding can last days, and rituals include the bride kicking over a pot of rice and dance competitions between Team Bride and Team Groom.

results.title: Anti-Semitism and the British Left
results.abstract: Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership of the Labour Party has alienated Britain’s Jews.

results.title: Suing Journalists in Mexico
results.abstract: The impact of Mexico’s new anticorruption law depends on the ability of journalists to do critical work without facing specious lawsuits.

results.title: The Flavors That Unite Syrians
results.abstract: Food is what defines the people of Syria, even after years of war and displacement.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

results.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
results.abstract: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.

results.title: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
results.abstract: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.

results.title: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
results.abstract: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.

results.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
results.abstract: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
results.byline: By JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
